Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: This Complaint is filed within the applicable statute of limitations for personal injury actions (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, § 2A).

Brown v. Kendall.proposition: As the owner/occupier and operator of a retail store open to the public and invitees, Defendant owed Plaintiff the duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to warn of latent or concealed dangers known or discoverable in the exercise of reasonable care, and generally to protect invitees from foreseeable hazards.

Donoghue v. Stevenson [1932] A.C. 562.proposition: As the owner/occupier and operator of a retail store open to the public and invitees, Defendant owed Plaintiff the duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to warn of latent or concealed dangers known or discoverable in the exercise of reasonable care, and generally to protect invitees from foreseeable hazards.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: The harm to Plaintiff — head injury (concussion), shoulder strain, medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and related losses — was a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s negligent storage and maintenance of merchandise and failure to use reasonable precautions to protect invitees.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns foreseeability of harms from negligent storage and maintenance of merchandise and failure to protect invitees, but Palsgraf involves railroad guards jostling a passenger’s package on a platform, not storage/maintenance of merchandise. More importantly, Cardozo’s opinion holds that the plaintiff’s injuries were NOT within the foreseeable orbit of risk and that, as to her, the guards’ conduct was not negligence at all. Thus, the case stands for the opposite principle: no liability where the harm to the plaintiff was not a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all. Nothing in the situation gave notice that the falling package had in it the potency of peril to persons thus removed. … If no hazard was apparent to the eye of ordinary vigilance, an act innocent and harmless, at least to outward seeming, with reference to her, did not take to itself the quality of a tort…”

MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..raw_text: MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y. 382 (1916)
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..proposition: Such breaches are negligent under established authorities recognizing a storeowner’s duty to protect invitees from hazards arising from the manner in which goods are stored and displayed.
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a storeowner’s duty to protect invitees from hazards created by how goods are stored or displayed on premises. MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co. deals with a manufacturer’s tort duty to remote purchasers (and, in this excerpt, the dissent’s view about privity and inherently dangerous products), not premises liability or duties of storeowners regarding display or storage of merchandise. The case therefore does not establish or discuss the proposition claimed and is an inapposite citation for that rule.
MacPherson v. Buick Motor Co., 217 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “The present suit is an action for negligence brought by the subvendee of the motor car against the manufacturer as the original vendor… It has heretofore been held in this state that the liability of the vendor of a manufactured article for negligence arising out of the existence of defects therein does not extend to strangers injured in consequence of such defects but is confined to the immediate vendee.”

Escola v. Coca\u2011Cola Bottling Co., 2.raw_text: Escola v. Coca‑Cola Bottling Co., 24 Cal.2d 453 (1944)
Escola v. Coca\u2011Cola Bottling Co., 2.proposition: Such breaches are negligent under established authorities recognizing a storeowner’s duty to protect invitees from hazards arising from the manner in which goods are stored and displayed.
Escola v. Coca\u2011Cola Bottling Co., 2.case_name: Escola v. Coca Cola Bottling Co.
Escola v. Coca\u2011Cola Bottling Co., 2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a storeowner’s duty to protect invitees from hazards created by the way goods are stored and displayed. Escola deals instead with a bottler’s negligence and the application of res ipsa loquitur to an exploding Coca‑Cola bottle supplied by the defendant, not with duties of a storeowner or hazards from store display methods. Nothing in the opinion discusses premises liability, invitees, or storage/display duties of retailers, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Escola v. Coca\u2011Cola Bottling Co., 2.relevant_excerpt: Plaintiff, a waitress in a restaurant, was injured when a bottle of Coca Cola broke in her hand. She alleged that defendant company, which had bottled and delivered the alleged defective bottle to her employer, was negligent in selling “bottles containing said beverage which on account of excessive pressure of gas or by reason of some defect in the bottle was dangerous . . . and likely to explode.” … Plaintiff then rested her case, having announced to the court that being unable to show any specific acts of negligence she relied completely on the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co..proposition: As the owner/occupier and operator of a retail store open to the public and invitees, Defendant owed Plaintiff the duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to warn of latent or concealed dangers known or discoverable in the exercise of reasonable care, and generally to protect invitees from foreseeable hazards.
